reviewText: This performance is absolutely exquisite - one gets an impression as she is watching this opera in Teatro Olimpico while in the company of Francesco Gonzaga or Isabella d'Este.  The very best of the music, including singers and the conductor, the staging, the costumes, the camera work - is here; it seems as this performance was made for aristocracy - so impeccable and unblemished is its quality.  I personally adore the respect that was paid to this immortal opus by the director/producers - thanks to them, we are transformed into a world of total beauty, far remote from such productions as another DVD with Rene Jacobs, Patricia Schumann, Richard Croft, where singers with questionable phisique were forced into erotic scenes for which they were not really endowed.  The only point towards Rene Jacobs' performance is Ottavia's aria "Ah! Addio Roma..." - I think the image created by Kathleen Kuhlmann is more convincing; her singing of is heartbreaking, while in Trudeliese Schmidt is too beautiful and too coquettish for a repudiated wife going into exile.How rewarding and pleasing for all five senses this production is; there are other performances made obviously during the same festival - such as L'orfeo, which is also in the same house and by Hanoncourt;  and Il Ritorno d'Ulisse.  From all standpoints, we see here the highest level of professionalism, appreciation and understanding of the opus and its epoch; and this makes it a true masterpiece.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I've had this wonderful performance on VHS and LD and when it became available on DVD, I ordered it immediately.  My only problem is that some of the singers use German pronunciation of Italian and it's very glaring.  In the midst of proper Italian pronunciation one hears a number of "qvesto" instead of "questo".  I'm sure that the director could have worked on this so that it didn't detract from what is an excellent performance of a work in which the Italian language plays such an important part.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This and the other 2 Monteverdi's by Harnoncourt are really worth owning.  For those who think Renaissance opera is boring, have a look at one of these.  The staging is stylish, costumes amazing, voices superb, orchestra perfect-in short these are anything but boring.
Title: N/A

reviewText: ... with Cantinflas singing Nerone. Try this: turn off the sound and watch this overblown, vulgar, corny, hammy production! It looks like nothing so much as a B grade Mexican telenovela set in baroque neverland. Every detail is exaggerated, every scene is laden with sappy distractions. The camera-work is straight out of I Love Lucy. It has NONE of the melancholy purity and gravitas of the music. It turns Busanello's complex, thoughtful libretto into a parody of Love.Then darken the picture and listen to the music. It's the music, after all, that really matters. Right? Well, the singing is dreadful. All of it. Not even the minor roles -- the three 'famigliari di Seneca' for instance -- are redeemed by singing well. In fact, they're horribly out of tune. The only singer who ISN'T frequently out of tune is the great bass Matti Salminen, but then he's dressed up as Merlin and hard to watch. Eric Tappy as Nerone is not only graceless and out of tune much of the time, but it's a mistake to have a tenor/baritone voice singing the role. It completely befuddles the final duet bewteen Nerone and Poppea, the musical apotheosis of the opera.I save my fiercest umbrage for Rachel Yakar, in the role of Poppea. Even if everyone else were the acme of vocal and dramatic perfection, Yakar would spoil this production. She sings like a crow on helium, and she looks like Bette Midler trying to play Cinderella.Wait, I have a little umbrage left for Nikolas Harnoncourt and his pit band, who have the schmaltzy habit of spilling out of the pit. I feel some anguish for the two poor shlemiels who had to play those kazoos fitted out to look like shawms or oboes, in lieu of any proper cornetto players. The pit band managed to make much of the music sound remarkably like Mantovani. Worst of all was Harnoncourt's exaggerated stop-start-stutter distortion of any rhythmic logic in the music. Voices, instruments, and stage direction all flung themselves like ham sandwiches before pearl divers.Yes yes, I KNOW this is a re-release of a classic production, one of three collaborations between Harnoncourt and Jean-Pierre Ponnelle which essentially threw open the opera stages of the world to further productions of 17th Century operas. Bravi tutti e grazie tanto! I've already reviewed the other two -- L'Orfeo and Il Ritorno d'Ulisse. They are all similar in production concept and costume style, but radically different, to my ears and eyes, in relative success. Ulisse is a joy to see and to hear: coherent dramaturgy and artful, tuneful singing. L'Orfeo falls squarely between, the cup half full or half empty.If you need a lot of costuming for your Poppea, at least the Glybdebourne production, with Maria Ewing, makes dramatic sense. Okay, Nikolas, repeat after me! Poppea is not a wacky Broadway Musical! Poppea is not slapstick comedy! Poppea is a sadder love story than Romeo and Juliet, in that the lovers do unite but only by dishonoring themselves and everything around.

reviewText: A great work of art like Poppea has many valid interpretations, yet I still find this one the most compelling version on DVD. It was the first Poppea for me and, although I was immediately besotted with the music, it took some other performances to realize its full brilliance. Initially, I craved for stronger portrayals of Nero and Otho, and my stratospheric expectations for staging were not fully met either--but I have changed my mind on all accounts except Otho. I refrain from enumerating the technical strengths of the singers, the staging, and the costumes--Rachel Yakar's Poppea and Trudeliese Schmidt's Octavia do outshine other portrayals though--and simply note the emotional and political sophistication of the production. Every gesture is designed to reflect the music and the resulting precision is ravishing. A key dynamic in Poppea is the vacillation between the violent realm of power and the sublime erotic bubble of Nero and Poppea. Some other productions try to pierce that bubble, presumably because it is `false' or `undeserved'. This one keeps the enchanting beauty intact and lets the viewer reach her own conclusions. As for Nero, although mezzo-sopranos in trouser roles can be excellent, he has to be sung by a tenor as is done here. As gorgeous of a tenor as can be found in fact! Eric Tappy's Nero is a fairly handsome egotist, but I wish that Ponnelle had pursued the interplay between affection and self-adulation even further.To those who prefer recordings of live performances: so do I, but Harnoncourt and Ponnelle are worth an exception. As a musical drama of immense immersive power, this is opera at its best.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "The Coronation of Poppea" is Monteverdi's last--and, many would say, greatest--opera.  This video of "Poppea" was filmed in 1979 in connection with performances at the Zurich Opera House.  Directed by Jean-Pierre Ponnelle, the opera is presented as it might have been seen at its 1643 premiere in Venice.  But although the set and costumes are baroque, the actions and emotions are contemporary, and the production is both visually and dramatically appealing.As always, conductor Nikolaus Harnoncourt finds the full measure of drama in the music.  For the opera house, Harnoncourt's performing version differs in two major respects from that of his 1974 audio recording (available on Teldec CD).  First, some cuts are made.  (The video runs for 162 minutes, the audio for 215 minutes.)  Second, the role of Nero is sung by a tenor (Eric Tappy) instead of a soprano.  The vocal and instrumental performances are uniformly excellent, as is the remastered sound.  (The boy soprano who sings Amore is outstanding.)Paul Van de Water
Title: N/A

reviewText: I agree with the negative reviewer--the acting is way too kitchy and the singing is cloying.Poppea is a serious work, and much better videos are available.

reviewText: Baroque Opera is not everyone's cup of tea. But this opera is perhaps the greatest work by Monteverdi and it has stood the test of time. There are many performances available, some quite good, some dreadful.This is probably one of the most visually and aurally delightful.It's a bit disconcerting at first because the singers/actors (they act in this one a lot, you have to watch them carefully to get all the nuance) are dressed in 17th century costumes instead of the expected Roman garb. I seem to remember reading that the director called for this because he felt this was how it would have been originally staged. Elaborate ancient Roman costumes might not have been in the 17th century budget? Regardless, it is a magnificent performance and production.Plot:Considering the morality of the time and the power of the Catholic Church, it is hard to imagine how Monteverdi got away with this amazingly beautiful piece of very 'naughty' shenanigans. Perhaps his music was so compelling that the "moral guardians of the time" forgave him and let it slide.You see, there is no moral redeeming quality in the story, but it is based on history and the actual events had little redeeming quality in them either!The story is a fantasy about how Emperor Nero got involved with prostitute/courtesan Poppea, sent his wife - Octavia - into exile (thus divorcing her) and elevated Poppea to the rank of Empress. You can hardly blame him. Poppea's a woman obsessed with using  her considerable "charms" (among other things) to get to power by playing on Nero's lust and vanity, something that Monteverdi plays up brilliantly in his music, and that the producers of this version staged with equal brilliance, and just a bit of tongue-in-cheek humor.There are several sub-plots in the opera, all built around love (or lust, depending on how you view the world), as well as betrayal, attempted murder, and state demanded suicide. What a mix! Yet that was the world of Nero's time. Monteverdi was our first "History Channel".The opera does the opposite of what we would expect- living in the time of censorship and 'decency'. Good does NOT triumph over evil. Instead, love, lust, and ambition triumph over all  In fact, Cupid, the god of love, plays a prominent role musically and on-stage. He's got a bet going with the goddesses of Fortune and Virtue that he can change the destiny of the world. He wins, hands down.This is a deliciously seductive opera and production - which I feel has been played just right - with a great mix of humor. Nero makes amazing faces throughout his performance, and there are some charming vignettes among minor characters (the nurse Arnalta almost steals the show). There are even two characters who appear on stage and fall in love, for no reason whatsoever than to perform a delicious love duet!Things get so rambunctious that even some members of the baroque orchestra jump up on stage to dance and perform with the singers. It's serious opera with a charming twist that brought a smile to my face. But it isn't 'comic opera' by any means. It is a serious work, made lighthearted so it is more palatable to modern tastes than a more 'purist' version would be.The Singers:They are all marvelous. They carry their lines to perfection, and accent them with movement and facial and body expression that can only be captured on film. They are as delightful to watch as to hear. They keep the opera moving (literally) and avoid the issue common to many early operas of people standing on stage, stiffly singing, and then exiting.The Orchestra:It's made up of what seem to be genuine Baroque instruments, and the musicians are also dressed in 17th century 'suits'-- black 'jerkins', tight pants, with white ruffled shirts, so they look the part. They are lively in their performance when we seem them in ensemble, and as I pointed out, they sometimes get on stage and interact with the actors. It's a twist that adds to the fun. The music has a satisfying 'depth' and moves along at a very nice pace. Bravo Orchestra!Conclusion:Serious opera taken too seriously can bog down and drag. Baroque opera is very serious (consider the time and the themes - all based on ancient classical subjects) and uses musical forms that are hard for many modern listeners to wrap their musical hearts around. We have the advantage of hundreds of years of musical development, ironically influenced by Monteverdi himself, but we can't expect it to be present when it is just being invented.In this opera we are at the birth of the Operatic art form. Monteverdi's vision was that of a compelling story (and with all the sexual innuendos, he got the compelling part right in Poppea) supported by music.This is a concept that we carry on today in movie soundtracks, where the music supports the action.As musical innovation, this production follows his lead and invents something of a 'new' performance style. It treats a serious subject seriously, but with light twists thrown in, giving what could easily seem dead and dreadful, a palatable and entertaining spin.And then there's the music itself... what a delight.If you can relax your musical purity a bit, and greatly let down any need for censorship, you might enjoy this performance more than you can imagine.
summary: Brilliant Performance With Delightful Twists - Highly Recommended
Title: N/A
